Zakaria was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his third loan. He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizers. In the future, Zakaria hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Elise

texts.en:
Elise was born in 1964 in Abomey, a major historical town in Benin. She moved to Cotonou, Benin's largest city, 15 years ago. She lives with her husband, Daniel, and two of their four children. All of their children are schooled.

For the past 13 years, Elise has sold meals from her stall in the Sama-Lémé district. This is her 8th loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. This loan will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. She cites her proactivity as her greatest attribute as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to prepare food

loans.name: Dative

texts.en: Dative is 48 years old and is married with seven children between the ages 10 and 25 years old. She has been selling shoes and bags for four years and her business is well-organized. She works from 7am until 7pm every day. She has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. Dative will reinvest the profits in her business and save for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more shoes and bags

loans.name: Luis Alfredo

texts.es:
Luis de 24 años, es un hombre inspirado en su trabajo que desde muy joven inicio esta actividad ya que es una tradición familiar y abrió su propia papelería.

El labora de 8H00am a 7H00pm en la venta de de su papelería con el apoyo de su esposa. con la ayuda del prestamos quiere comprar cuadernos, zapatos, y variados mercadería. lo que mas anhela es que su papelería crezca con variedad de artículos para que le genere mas ingresos.
texts.en:
Luis is 24 years old and he is a man that is inspired in his work. He started this business since he was very young, especially because it is a family tradition. He opened his own office supply store. 

He works from 8am to 7pm selling office supplies and he has his wife's support. With help of this loan he wants to purchase notebooks, shoes, and various merchandise. What he most wishes for is to have his office supply store grow and to have a variety of merchandise to generate more income.

loans.use: to purchase notebooks, shoes, and various office supplies.

loans.name: Baktykan's Group

texts.en:
Baktykan U. is the treasurer of this group. She is 42 years old, married, and has two adult children. Five months ago with the initial investment of 30,000 soms, Baktykan opened a pavilion and started to sell groceries. She earns 20,800 soms per month. With money from the loan, she wants to purchase more drinks, foodstuffs, macaroni. etc. In the future Baktykan hopes to purchase a three-room flat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase drinks and foodstuff

loans.name: 83 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thiệp has a manufacturing business sewing clothes. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Thiệp is 56 years old and she is married. She has 4 children.

Thiệp is the group leader of the 18.5.83 Quảng Hưng solidarity group, which consists of 4 members. She lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, a urban town in Thanh Hoa province. This is her first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Thiệp has been involved in this business for 3 years.

The main harship that Thiệp faces in her business is the lack of capital. In the future, Thiệp hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to buy cloth to make clothes.

loans.name: Marianela

texts.es:
Marianela es socia del Banco Comunal Palmeras, tiene 34 años, es soltera, y tiene un hijo de 8 meses. Se dedica a la venta de plantas ornamentales, frutales, forestales. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de plantas y macetas para surtir su negocio.
Maríanela tiene un puesto de plantas ornamentales, frutales, forestales en Canán Alto y le va bien. Ingresó a FINCA Perú, por la invitación de su tía. Con éste es el segundo ciclo que está. Le parece interesante hay muchos facilidades en los prestamos y por las capacitaciones que da su promotora. Se inculca la cultura del ahorro. Con su ahorro se compró una cocina. Su sueño es ahorrar y poder comprarse un terreno y tener un vivero.
texts.en:
Marianela is a member of the Palmeras community bank.  She is 34 years old, single, and has an 8 month-old son.  Her business is selling ornamental plants, fruit plants and native plants.  She will invest the loan that she is requesting in buying plants and plant pots with which to stock her business.  

Marianela has a plant stall in Canán Alto and her business is doing well.  She joined FINCA Peru through an invitation from one of her aunts.

This is Marianela's second loan cycle.  She likes the ease of the loans and the training that she receives from her loan officer.  FINCA Peru instill in their members a culture of saving.   With her savings, Marianela has bought herself a stove.  Her dream is to save up and be able to buy a plot of land and start a [plant] nursery.

loans.use: to buy plants and plant pots

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: install a tile floor at his house.

loans.name: Lupe

texts.es:
La señora Lupe es socia del banco comunal Las Tigresas del Distrito De Calleria, Departamento De Ucayali, tiene 50 años de edad y un hijo.
Lleva cuatro años trabajando con los préstamos de Manuela Ramos, se dedica a la venta de picarones (dulce peruano), el cual prepara por las tarde en el patio de su casa, tiene un par de mesas para comodidad de sus clientes.
Con su nuevo préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles comprará: 2 cientos de platos descartables, ½ saco de azúcar, para hacer su miel, ¼ de clavo de olor, ¼ de canela, 1 vainilla, ¼ de anís, 1 galón de aceite, 1 perol.
Sus ganancias le sirve para solventar sus propios gastos, porque vive sola consu hijo en la casa de su mamá y no tiene muchos gastos.  Está muy tranquila porque Manuela Ramos la sigue apoyando.
texts.en: Lupe is a member of the 'Las Tigresas' (The Tigresses) community bank which is located in Calleria district, in Ucayali department. She is 50 years old and has one child. Lupe has been working with Manuela Ramos loans for four years. Her business is selling 'picarones' (a Peruvian dessert). She prepares them in the afternoons, in the patio area outside her home. She has a couple of tables for her customers' convenience. With this new loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles, Lupe will buy: 200 disposable plates, half a sack of sugar for making her honey syrup, quarter of a bag of cloves, quarter of a bag of cinnamon, 1 lot of vanilla, quarter of a bag of aniseed, 1 gallon of oil and 1 pot. Lupe uses her profits to cover her own expenses as she lives with her son in her mom's house and doesn't have many expenses. She is very happy that Manuela Ramos continue to support her.

loans.use: to buy a pot, disposable plates and ingredients

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.ru: Зулфия жительница Файзабадского района. Ей 43 года. Она разведена. У нее детей нет. Она имеет средне - специальное образование, учительница. По профессии Зулфия проработала 10 лет. На сегодняшний день она у себя дома занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Этим видом деятельности она занимается уже три года. Кредит берет для приобретения швейной машинки.
texts.en: Zulfiya lives in the Fayzabad district.  She is 43 years old, divorced and has no children.  She has a secondary-specialized education as a teacher.  Zulfiya has worked in her field for 10 years.  Today, she is involved in sewing national dresses at her home.  She has been in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of a sewing machine.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Susie

texts.en: Susie is 40 years old and lives in Congo Town. She is a widow and has five children, one of whom lives at home with her. For the past five years Susie has been running a small restaurant in her community selling delicious Liberian dishes. Sometime she has the problem of few customers. Susie is requesting a loan to purchase rice, fish and oil for her business. She plans to buy a plot of land and build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase rice, fish and oil for her business.

loans.name: Maxwell

texts.en: Maxwell wants a loan to buy crates of soda for resale. He has been trading in beverages for the last five years. Twenty-seven years old, Maxwell hails from Kyenjojo District of Uganda. He is married, and a father of four children between the ages of one and five. He lives with his family in a permanent house. Having started as an agriculturalist on a small basis, he saved the money to start his current business. His dream is to become a wholesaler, and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy crates of soda for resale.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is a determined, 22-year-old businessman. He is single. 

He has been managing a business of motorbike transportation to make a living. His dream is to have several motorbikes for transportation. In five years, he hopes to be using a bus for transportation.
 
He is requesting for a loan of 10,000 KES to be used for the maintenance of his motorbike. 

Thanks to Faulu Kenya,he has been enabled to save and also to access credit.

loans.use: To service his motorbike.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.es:
La  socia pertenece al banco comunal “SOLIDARIDAD-CACHIMAYO” el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Cachimayo, en la Provincia de Urubamba y Departamento de Cusco.

La  socia Visitacion; tiene 60 años de edad,  la socia es casada; la socia tiene 7 hijos  los cuales son todos ellos independientes; La socia se dedica la crianza de animales menores como gallinas, chanchos los cuales compra, cría y vende, la socia también tiene un par de vacas, ahora ella desea  empezar a invertir en la compra de ganados vacunos, para la crianza, reproducción y venta final. La socia es una señora muy carismática y trabajadora, ella desea seguir en actividad y con la ilusión de comprar sus vacas para la venta de los derivados y la reproducción de sus ganados, ella quiere dejarles a sus hijos el ejemplo de que no hay edad para hacer los sueños realidad, ella soñó en tener una buena cantidad considerable de cabezas de ganados vacunos, lo que significa  tener  en su casa vacas como mínimo un numero de 10, y criarlas, alimentarlas y hacerlas procrear y ese fue su sueño. La socia ahora solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de vacas terneras.

La  socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the “SOLIDARIDAD-CACHIMAYO” communal bank, which is located in the district of Cachimayo, in the province of Urubamba and department of Cusco.

The member, Visitación, is 60 years old, married and has 7 children, all of whom are adults. She works raising young animals, like chickens, and pigs which she buys, raises and sells. She also has a pair of cows and now she wants to begin buying cattle to riase, reproduce and in the end, sell.

Visitación is a very charismatic and hardworking woman. She wants to continue doing this work, with the dream of buying cows in order to breed them and sell their offspring. She wants to leave her children with the example that old age does not prevent one’s dreams from coming true. She dreamed of having a large number of heads of cattle, which means having a minimum of 10 at her house, raising them, feeding them, breeding them and that was her dream. She is currently requesting the loan to invest in female calves.

Visitación is grateful for the support provided her and is committed to making her payments on time

loans.use: to buy female calves.

loans.name: Jessica Elizabeth

texts.es:
Jessica de 24 años es una joven emprendedora que tiene un negocio de cabinas y recargas telefónicas. Comenzó a trabajar ayudándole a la mama en el negocio familiar que tenían pero como quería mejorar su situación financiera decidió tener su propio negocio. 

En la actualidad tiene su negocio de cabinas y recargas telefónicas. Trabaja con la compañía “Claro” quien le comprar los minutos para que sus clientes tengan las llamadas que necesitan.  Tiene muchas aspiraciones para mejorar sus finanzas por eso desea el préstamo para comprar minutos a la compañía y así cumplir con las exigencias de sus clientes para llamadas internacionales.
texts.en:
Jessica, 24, is a young entrepreneur who has a business of telephone booths and cell phone minutes. She started out helping her mother in their family business, but she wanted to improve her financial situation so she decided to open her own business. 

Currently her business has phone booths and cell phone minutes. She works with the company "Claro", buying minutes from them so that her customers can make the calls they need to. She has aspirations of improving her finances and for that reason she wants a loan to buy minutes from the company and meet the demands of her clients for making international calls.

loans.use: to buy telephone minutes.

loans.name: Ramzi

texts.en:
Ramzi, a 35-year-old married father of three sons and two daughters, is a Palestinian National Authority employee who earns a decent salary. Ramzi wants to purchase a new rickshaw in order to work extra hours and increase the family income, but the amount of money he has isn't sufficient. He is therefore requesting a loan from FATEN, to be repaid monthly which, when combined with his savings, will enable Ramzi to make the purchase and help him to improve his family's living conditions.

About This Loan Product:

FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan.

For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: to purchase a new rickshaw.

loans.name: Esther Mawia

texts.en: Esther is a 39-year-old married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from six years to twelve years. She describes herself to be quiet and likes sharing ideas. She operates a retail shop where she sells items such as rice, sugar, bread, flour, and detergents. She has been involved in this business for fourteen years. Her business is located in a busy shopping center. She describes her biggest business challenge to be financial constraints. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy cereals for selling at the retail shop. Her business goal is to grow her business into a wholesale one within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to the university level.

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell at the general store

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim is a weaver. She is a widow and a mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of her children are married and the other one has full-time employment. She lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Yim is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to continue her weaving business by purchasing weaving materials.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Jesulome Group

texts.fr: Le groupement JESULOME est formé de treize personnes qui se connaissent de part leurs activités. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Julienne est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Julienne est âgée de 41 ans, et est mariée à un revendeur du nom de Albert. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés dont trois à leur charge. Julienne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis une trentaine d’année, Julienne vend de la farine de manioc qu'elle produit à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Julienne vend des fruits. Ce qui lui permet d’assurer ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la famille. Julienne achète ses produits dans un village du Bénin et les revend dans une ville du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Julienne et les autres membres du groupement JESULOME sollicitent un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur permettra de renforcer leur activité et d'accroître leur fonds de roulement, afin de mieux répondre à la demande de leur clientèle.
texts.en: The JESULOME group is made up of thirteen people who know each other apart from their businesses.  The group representative, named Julienne, has her hand raised in the photo.  Julienne is 41 years old and married to a reseller named Albert.  The couple has four children, all of whom have attended school and three of whom are under their care.  Julienne did not go to school.  For the last 30 years she has been selling manioc flour, which she makes at home.  In addition to this business, she sells fruits.  This allows her to pay the family's expenses, along with help from her husband.  Julienne buys her products in a village in Benin and resells them in a city in Benin.  This is the first time that she and the other members of the JESULOME group have requested a loan through ALIDé. This loan will allow them to increase their business activities and their operating funds, in order to better respond to demand from their customers.

loans.use: to buy bags of manioc.

loans.name: Mahuna Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUNA est formé de trois personnes qui résident dans la même zone. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Clarisse est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Clarisse est âgée de 32 ans, et est mariée à un certain Jean Marie. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous à leur charge et dont certains sont scolarisés. En plus de leurs enfants, Clarisse et son mari ont un autre enfant vivant à leur charge. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins du ménage. Clarisse n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la coiffure, activité qu'elle exerce depuis quatre ans et qui lui permet d'assurer ses différentes charges. Parallèlement à cette activité, Clarisse vend des mèches et des produits de beauté dans son atelier situé dans son quartier.Clarisse achète ses produits dans un marché du Bénin. C’est la troisième fois que Clarisse et les autres membres du groupe MAHUNA sollicitent un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur permettra de renforcer leur activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de leur clientèle. Les crédits précédents ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
MAHUNA Group is made up of three women who live in the same area. The group's representative, named Clarisse, is the one raising her hand in the photograph.

She's 32 years old and married to one Jean Marie. The couple has four children whom they have to support. Some of them attend school.

In addition to their own children, Clarisse and her husband have another child to support. The couple provides for the household together.

Clarisse never attended school, but got trained in hairdressing, a business she's been running for four years and which enables her to provide for herself.

In parallel, Clarisse sells hair extensions and beauty products in her workshop located in her neighborhood. She purchases her supplies in a market in Benin.

This is the third time that Clarisse and the other members of the MAHUNA Group are seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, ALIDé. This loan will enable them to bolster their businesses in order to better meet customer demand.

Previous loans were repaid without problems.

loans.use: to buy hair extensions and beauty products

loans.name: Evalyne

texts.en:
Evalyne is married and blessed with two children who are in school. She has been selling clothes for the last thirteen years to support her family. She also does farming to increase her income. She has employed one person to assist her manage the business. 

Evalyne has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting for a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to add to her stock of clothes for resale. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business.

loans.use: buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more retail stock, such as sugar, salt, and flour.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is 23 years old and a single mother with two children.

She has been into her business for the last 4 years, from which she earns a monthly income of Kes 10,000. She is applying for her first loan of Kes 30,000. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer.

She hopes to use the funds to buy more clothes and venture in a charcoal business to help educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale and stocks of charcoal

loans.name: Nune

texts.en: Nune lives in Yerevan with her husband and son who is a student. Nune has opened a little grocery this year to have a stable source of income. Nune has applied for this loan to develop her business. With the loan's help she plans to purchase goods for her shop. This loan will help Nune to continue successfully running the shop and make the business more profitable. Nune will get more income and ensure a better future for her family.

loans.use: to pay for inventory.

loans.name: Domitile

texts.en:
Domitile is 52 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 8 and 32 years, 4 of them go to school. He is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 19 years.  Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Ake

texts.en:
P. is married with 7 children and 18 grandchidren. 

She has two businesses. She runs a small general store in her village of Moataa. She also makes special mats.

She is a member of one of the best village groups in the SPBD program, and winner of the first best cente r prize in 2001.

She has paid back more than 5 loans since joining SPBD and these loans have helped her build her store, stock her store as well as do some home improvements including a new roof. With this particular loan she needs to buy a fridge/freezer as the one she has is outgrown the demand for frozen meat in the neighbourhood. She also will put flywire on the house to protect it from mosquitoes. Moataa village is located in a protrected mangrove area on the outskirts of Apia.

Another activity she has is making special mats as the one which is in the photo. Mats are very popular in Samoa. The one pictured here will be used for decoration, not walking on.

loans.use: Buy stock for shop, a fridge/freezer and flywire for the house for security and keep ou mosquitos

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Ann Nyakeru Gichohi intends to buy household goods in bulk for the retail shop

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en: Alphonsine runs a restaurant and sells beverages. She has been in business since 1995. In 2004, Alphonsine joined one of Hope’s groups (a DRCongo Microfinance program) and received 7 loans, all of which she has paid back regularly. She has worked hard to develop her business. With the high demand of the clients, Alphonsine is requesting a loan of $620 to buy food in bulk for her restaurant and improve the facility in order to better serve her clients and increase her income.  She hopes to generate more profit to support her family. Alphonsine is 57 years old and a mother of six children. She also cares for two other children.

loans.use: To purchase food in bulk for her restaurant

loans.name: Nusrat

texts.en: “I require a loan to help my husband set up his new barber unit and purchase equipment for it. The income will help continue to put food on the table and keep our children in primary school. We don’t have a barber shop yet, but my husband works on the roadside. Once day when his business expands, I hope he can operate from a proper barber shop.” Nusrat B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase equipment

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo S. is a mother of three children and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works as a landlord building different rooms and renting them to the people in her area. She generally generates around $2 each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning $2 a day, one of her children is employed at a garment factory and the rest  are students. Because of her growing customer demand Mrs. Keo S. has recently applied for a loan to build more rooms which will enable her to generate  additional income.

loans.use: To build more rooms enabling her to generate additional income.

loans.name: Sarwati

texts.en: Sarwati is 45 years old and is married with one son. Her husband passed away and now she is working on her own. She started her business after she became a member of MBK. She needs a IDR 1,000,000 loan, and intends to use it for buying fertilizer and seeds for her farm. Sarwati usually earns $10 per day and she hopes that the loan will help her business generate more income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for her farm

loans.name: Manuela's Group

texts.es:
Manuela, Sabina, and Graciela are members of the Despertar Community Bank since 12, 11 and 10 years ago. At their community bank they learn values, self-esteem, and how to move their households forward. They tell us that at their beginnings no one wanted to take the risk of assuming the job of the board of directors due to fear. Now things are different and they face the challenges ahead

Manuela sells cereals and processed products like moron, manioc, wheat and peeled corn which she elaborates. In the meantime, Sabina makes bricks and Graciela has a grocery stores. Their loans are in the amounts of 600 soles (Peruvian currency0, 1000 soles, and 800 soles respectively. They will invest the money in buying wheat, barley, corn, chick peas, rice, lima beans, milk, oil, preserves, sugar, soap, and to pay for laborers. They will use their savings to increase the capital of their businesses. The dreams of Manuela, Sabina and Graciela are to have a stable location where they can sell their products, have a bigger business, have a hardware store, that her children become professionals, and to be able to improve their houses and be able to rent them

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Manuela, Sabina y Graciela son socias del Banco Comunal Despertar hace 12, 11 y 10 años respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal les enseñaron los valores, la autoestima y a llevar adelante su hogar. Ellas cuentan que en un inicio nadie quería asumir cargos D. la junta directiva por temor, ahora las cosas son diferentes y asumen los retos. Manuela venD. cereales y productos procesados como morón, ulpada, trigo y maíz pelado que ella misma hace, mientras que Sabina fabrica ladrillos D. construcción y Graciela tiene su tienda D. abarrotes. Sus préstamos son D. 600 soles, 1000 soles y 800 soles que los invertirán en la compra D. trigo, cebada, maíz, garbanzo, pallar, arroz, leche, aceite, conservas, azúcar, jabón y para el pago D. la mano D. obra (peones). Sus ahorros los utilizarán para aumentar el capital D. su negocio. Los sueños D. Manuela, Sabina y Graciela son tener un puesto estable para poder vender sus productos, tener un negocio mas granD., tener una ferretería, que sus hijos sean profesionales y mejorar su casa para poder arrendar.

loans.use: Their loans are in the amounts of 600 soles (Peruvian currency0, 1000 soles, and 800 soles respectively.  They will invest the money in buying wheat, barley, corn, chick peas, rice, lima beans, milk, oil, preserves, sugar, soap, and to pay for laborers.

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en: I am Sakina R. from the small town of Chichawatni, Pakistan. My husband transports goods on a donkey cart and one of my sons operate a cloth shop. Last year, we took a loan for my husband’s business and his business became stable.  This year we request a loan for my son’s clothing sales store. My group members are: Kishwer B., who requests a loan for her son’s pharmacy, Sakina B., who requests a loan to buy her son a rickshaw, and Shahnaz B., who will invest in their restaurant. All these women are very cooperative and make their repayments on time.

loans.use: To expand clothing business

loans.name: Pedro Pablo

texts.es:
Pedro Pablo Sanchez is a gentleman native of Villanueva located in the city of Ghinandega in Nicaragua. For a long time he has been thinking of ways of getting ahead and improving his financial condition, this brought him to the decision to start his own business of selling bread in small quantities.

Currently Mr. Pedro Sanchez has 10 years invested in this business and with great effort he is able to support his two school age children.

It is important to stress that Mr. Pedro finds himself with the need to invest in his small company and due to the lack of resources is turning to Ceprodel for a loan which will enable him to improve the condition of his business and acquire raw materials so that he can continue to support his family. He has a history of 4 loans with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Pedro Pablo S. es un caballero originario de Villanueva ubicada en la ciudad de Chinandega de Nicaragua. Por mucho tiempo buscó la manera de salir adelante para mejorar su condición económica lo que lo llevo a pensar en poner su propio negocio y se decidió por vender pan pero en pequeñas cantidades.

Actualmente, el señor Pedro S. lleva 10 años de dedicarse a este negocio y con mucho esfuerzo lo realiza para mantener a sus 2 hijos en edad escolar.

Es necesario destacar que el señor Pedro atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en su negocio y por ser de escasos recursos acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le ayuden a mejorar la condición del negocio y comprar materia prima para continuar manteniendo su núcleo familiar. Su record crediticio es de 4 créditos con Ceprodel

loans.use: Expansion of the business

loans.name: Otilia

texts.pt:
Otilia G. is 24 years old and native to the district of Matutuine in the province of Maputo. As a child she did not have the opportunity to study, and due to her parents' lack of conditions she only attended school until the 7th grade. As a result she found herself obliged to go to South Africa to search for work. However, at her place of employment she came to marry a Mozambican man in that neighboring country. She says that they lived there for some time and the conditions did not improve so they had to return to Mozambique.

As she is alone at home and her current house offers only minimum security, she proposed to her husband that they solicit a loan so they could construct a home with conventional materials. This loan goes to purchase cement and labor since some materials they had already acquired with their family savings. She envisions that after finishing her home and furnishings that she will begin other investments like raising cattle or goats.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Otilia G., de 24 anos de idade, natural do Distrito de Matutuine, provincia da Maputo, durante a sua infancia não teve possibilidade de estudar, disse devido a falta de condiçoes dos pais, tendo terminado na 7ª Classe. Assim, viu se obrigada a ir para Africa do Sul procurar emprego. Porem, no lugar de emprego veio o casamento com um Mocambicano residente naquele Pais vizinho. Diz que viveram la por um tempo e as condiçoes nao favoreceram teve de voltar a Moçambique e como ela está sozinha no lar e a casa que tem nao lhe oferece minimas condicoes de segurança propos ao marido para irem solicitarem emprestimo de forma a construir uma com material convencional. O emprestimo de 30.000,00MT foi para compra de cimento e pagamento de mao de obra, pois uma parte de material ja tinham adquirido com poupancas familiares. Tem como perpectivas depois de terminar as construcoes mobilar e iniciar com outros investimentos tipo criacao de gado bovino ou caprino.

loans.use: To buy materials to build family house

loans.name: Salelologa Tumupapa Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
Miranda T., 25, is married to a laborer and has three children. She is starting a business selling taro. Her husband will do the farming. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, two bush knives, a filing, and 1,500 taro roots. She will sell her produce one day a week and plans to earn a net weekly cash flow of 120 Tala (~48 USD).

Galegale A., 26, is single with no children. For over two years, she has sold taro, bananas, and yams in the Salelologa market on Fridays. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, four knives, two filings, and a spade. With this expansion, she expects to earn net cash flow per week of 100 Tala (~ 40 USD).

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, etc.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a 45 year old mother of five. Her eldest child is married and the other four are still in school. She has two separate businesses: a half acre sweet potato plantation; and a charcoal selling business. The sweet potato plantation bears crops every 4 months which she can sell for $50 - although she has to hire someone to harvest the crop at a cost of $13. She buys bags of charcoal for $10 and sells them for $14. Margret is still looking for a loan to enable her to continue buying charcoal.  Her profits are all spent on school fees and she needs the loan to repurchase stock.

loans.use: To buy charcoal stock.

loans.name: Kamandar

texts.en: Kamandar was born in 1980. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli. He is now settled in the Fuzuli region. Kamandar is single. Five years ago he started a dairy business. He needs a loan of $975 to buy a cow.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Bocc Diom 1 Group

texts.fr:
With our first loan with Kiva, we were able to buy cattle and sheep, which we raised and fattened, allowing us to resell them in the weekly markets around the village of Mboul.  However, after benefiting from our first loan, we would like a second loan to continue with our business by increasing our capital and buying more cattle and sheep.  

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer. 

Aprés avoir bénéficié d'un premier prêt kiva qui nous a permis d'acheter des bovins et ovins que nous avons élévé en les engraissant, nous avons pu les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires situés aux alentours du village de Mboul. 
Cependant, nous souhaiterions être financés une deuxiéme fois pour pouvoir continuer nos activités en ayant un plus grand capital qui nous nous permettra d'acheter beaucoup de bovins et ovins.

loans.use: Raise cattle and sheep

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili J. S. is 30 years old and married with four children, ages9, 7, 5 and 2.  She has been selling charcoal and clothing since 2006. Every day, she works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $90.
Pili now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more charcoal  for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Afoutouhlin

texts.fr:
Né le 24 juin 1977 à Lomé, monsieur K. Afoutouhlin est un jeune célibataire très endurant qui a ouvert son bar « BOOM RANG » dans la ville de Lomé. Etant donné qu’il est en chômage il a rassemblé ses fonds et a fait une étude se son milieu pour voir ce qui peut être bien consommé par la population de son quartier. Après cette étude il a ouvert son bar en 2007 et vend très bien.
Ce premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’augmenter les produits dans son stock et de pouvoir bien servir ses clients.
A cet effet, il sollicite ce crédit pour s’approvisionner avec 65 casiers de bière et 20 casiers de sucrerie.
texts.en:
Born on June 24, 1977 in Lomé, Mr. Afoutouhlin K. is a young, determined, single gentleman who opened his bar “BOOM RANG” in the city of Lomé. Given that he was unemployed, he gathered his funds and performed a study of his community to see what services were in demand in his area. After this study, he opened his bar in 2007 and is selling successfully. The request of his first loan will allow him to increase his stock of products and better serve his clients. For this reason he is requesting a loan to add 65 cases of beer and 20 cases of candy to his inventory.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of beverages to supply the bar

loans.name: Sesselou Group

texts.fr: Comme l’écovillage de Palmarin (http://www.sem-fund.org/palmarinfr.php) est une zone côtière de grande production de Sel. Le groupement Sesselou, pour lutter contre l’oisiveté et aider les femmes à commercialiser le sel, a décidé de travailler dans le marché du sel d’où son exploitation et sa commercialisation.  Avec le prêt, ils vont exploiter le sel après l’avoir extrait. Ne disposant pas encore de machines à coudre pour ensacher le produit fini,  Ils vont acheter des ficelles, aiguilles, sacs, pour y mettre le sel et l’exporter vers d’autres contrées Joal, Djiffer et même vers  la Gambie.
texts.en:
Since the ecovillage Palmarin (http://www.sem-fund.org/palmarinfr.php) is located in a costal area which produces a great amount of salt, the Sesselou group decided to exploit an commercialize salt, to fight idleness, and help women with this business. With this loan, they will extract salt and exploit it. Lacking sewing machines to make bags to pack the product, they will buy strings, needles and sacks to pack salt and export it to other regions such as Joal, Djiffer, and even to Gambia.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To exploit and sell salt

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Coumba Baldé, 46 ans, mariée, 08 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Samba 15 ans 1  depuis 6 ans. Elle veut renforcer son activité de vente de moutons et d’huile de palme. Les revenus  tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b> Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Coumba Baldé, 46, married and raising 8 children, has been a member of the village bank of Samba for 6 years. She wants to boost her business selling sheep and palm oil. The income from her businesss allows her to help support her family. She is requesting a loan that will be reimbursed after 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of sheep and palm oil

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is a business woman in Accra. She trades in Dumas clothes, lace materials, and ladies shoes. She is 42 years old, married, and blessed with two kids who are currently in school. Beatrice is very supportive of her family through her trading business. Beatrice treks to the neighboring country to purchase her bulk supplies. She has been selling for the past seven years, but progress has been persistently slow due to insufficient funds. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her inventory and vitalize her business growth, ultimately allowing her to save more money so that she can provide her children with quality education. She belongs to the group called the Somuyie Trust Group. The group members provide assistance and support to one another to repay the loan. Her photograph was taken at a group meeting.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of Dumas clothes, lace materials, shoes to increase her inventory and sales.

loans.name: Las Populares Group

texts.es:
G/S LAS POPULARES, nace por la necesidad de hacer crecer su negocio, esta miembros del g/s son vecinas  viven en la ciudad de Nindiri,  son de condición humildes, a veces expresivas otras muy calladas, son respetuosas y de trato muy amable. Iniciaron su negocio por la necesidad de obtener mayores  ingresos que les ayuden a soportar la carga económica de sus compañeros, comenzaron con solo venta de golosinas en un canasto, con los créditos de adim ellas han incrementado su negocio y ahora ofertan otros productos.

Doña Reina  ha  ofertado más productos básicos de primera necesidad, ella compra en el mercado de masaya  dos veces por semana, la demanda ella no la puede cubrir por falta de capital, es por eso que acide a adim para un financiamiento.
Las miembros de este g/s sueñan con llegar a tener una pulpería, debido a su tenacidad ellas saben que lo va a   lograr, ya que cuenta con la ayuda de su esposos e hijos mayores los cuales han sido muy colaboradores en los proyectos que emprende su mamá.
texts.en:
The group of associates, Las Populares, was born of the necessity to make thier business grow. The members of the group are neighbors that live in the city of Nindiri, are of humble backgrounds, at times very expressive at other very quiet, they are respectful and very friendly. The started their businesses in order to obtain better income that would help them support the economic responsibilities of their partners. They started by selling only snack out of a basket. With the loans from ADIM they have expanded their business and now offer more products. Reina has offered more products of basic necessity that she buys at the Masaya market twice a week. She is unable to cover the demand for goods due to lack of capital, which is why she came to ADIM for a loan. The members of this group of associates dream of having a store. Because of their tenacity, they know that it will happen, especially since they have the support of their husbands and grown children who have been very helpful in the projects taken on by their mothers.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business Capital; Supply their business; Satisfy demand for products.

loans.name: Mrs. Im Ry Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people who live in Preak Treing village in Kandal province formed the village bank. They will use the loan for a variety of purposes. Mrs. Im R. owns a small groceR. store in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for the loan to buy more groceR. products for her inventoR.. Her husband, Mr. Ruos Choeun, owns a rice mill that has been hired by a villager. Mrs. Im R. is 30-year-old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study. 

Four members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for the loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua N. has been trading in the local market of Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where she stays with her family. She is 22 years old with two children, one of whom is in school and the other, a baby. She is single and still lives with her parents. Akousa dropped out of school for financial reasons. It has been her dream to go back to the classroom. She is a busy trader who sells rice grain, plantains, pepper, onions and other food stuffs in the market. She does not have sufficient working capital to run her business.  With a loan of $350,  Akousahe believes her business will grow and that will enable her to increase her savings so that she can go to school this year. She would be grateful for that assistance. Akosua belongs to a village bank called ‘Nhyira Mma’ which means "Blessed Children".

loans.use: To purchase increased stock of palm oil, tin tomatoes, yams, onions, beans, maize, dried fish etc

loans.name: Noli

texts.en: Noli is a resident of Calamagui 1st village. He and his wife Lority are both 28 years old. They have a son named Daniel who is now two years old. Noli operates a tricycle transport business in their village, a livelihood activity where he generates income to support his family's needs. So his motorcycle will not become damaged beyond repair, Noli wanted to request a loan amounting to PHP6,000 for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle. He believes that hard work is the key to progress, thus he strives a lot.

loans.use: Motorcyle Repair and Maintenance

loans.name: Dupe

texts.en:
Dupe sells industrial chemicals and drinks. She learned her business in 3 months and she has been in this business for the past 8 years. Dupe is 45 years old and she has 5 children. Dupe lives in Agege and she has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 3 years.

Dupe’s business has been improving greatly, especially for the past 3 years when she started borrowing from LAPO Microfinance. Dupe is requesting the loan amount of N140, 000 to enable her to purchase more industrial chemicals and drinks to sell. She is very grateful for the loan given to her by LAPO Microfinance and Kiva. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and industrial chemicals to sell

loans.name: Rec Waterloo Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the R.E.C Primary School, Waterloo. R.E.C. Primary School Waterloo was founded in 1926 by the government. R.E.C Waterloo has a total number of 546 pupils and a total number of fourteen staff. Since 2006, when Nafisatu A. T. took over the administration of the school, R.E.C Primary School Waterloo has been producing good results at the National Primary School Exams (NPSE). However, like many schools in Sierra Leone, REC Waterloo lacks adequate classrooms, seating accommodations and adequate learning and teaching materials. This will be the first loan for teachers of the R.E.C Primary School from SMT/Kiva. Government salaries are usually quite small for teachers, thus making teaching an unattractive profession for many whose primary motivator is money. Many choose other jobs over teaching because of the small salary, thus starving the field of qualified personnel to teach the children. The few who remain in the classrooms have to find other ways of making ends meet. The vast majority of them engage in either businesses or agriculture or they provide extra tutorial classes for the children (although this is a practice the government is trying to stop).

Needless to say, loans from SMT are a great help to the teachers in order to boost their businesses or investing it in something productive. Many want to go to school but could not afford the cost. Some will want to buy pieces of furniture, but their monthly salary is not enough to let them do so. With a loan, they will be able to meet some of these needs. And with their monthly salaries, they can repay easily via a payroll deduction type of system. Nafisatu A. T. (left) is the head teacher of R.E.C Primary School Waterloo. She was born in Matotoka village, Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. She is fifty-four years of age and married with four children. One is already an adult and three are still attending schools. She has been a teacher for thirty-six years now. Nafisatu will use this loan to buy bundles of corrugated iron zinc to roof her house. She does not expect to complete the roofing of her house with this loan, but with subsequent loans, however, she will certainly complete the roofing of her house. This will bring happiness and joy to Nafisatu as it will relieve her of the burden of paying exorbitant rents.

loans.use: To buy corrugated iron zinc for house roof

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna O. manages a small store. She is 39, married and has three children in school. She could hardly keep up with the family finances, which is why she engages herself in business to supplement their limited income. Her husband is earning from his motorcycle. They work together to send all their children to school.

The purpose of her loan is to buy additional merchandise for her store. In that way, she could attract more buyers and earn a bigger profit.

CEVI is helping her grow her business even more. Now she receives not just CEVI loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Yubes

texts.es: Yubes tiene 34 años, vive con su esposo, quien trabaja como constructor de viviendas, tienen 3 hijos. Desde hace 3 años tiene una pequeña tienda que implementó en un espacio dentro de su casa, se inició con muy pocos productos, pero gracias a sus ventas diarias su negocio está creciendo muy rápido. Esta actividad, le ha dado a Yubes, la oportunidad de relacionarse con casi todos sus vecinos, que antes no conocía, y que por su carisma y buena atención, acuden regularmente a su bodega.  Adicionalmente, y como otra fuente de ingresos, Yube vende comida y bebidas por las noches en un espacio que acondiciona a diario fuera de su casa. Su anhelo es lograr que su tienda crezca y se convierta en un minimarket. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP, y le gusta trabajar con su grupo porque son organizados y coordinados en las actividades de su banco comunal. Con el dinero que solicita implementará su negocio, comprando los productos necesarios para surtir su bodega.
texts.en:
Yubes is 34 years old, lives with her husband who works in residential construction, and has three children. For the last 3 years she has been running a small store that she set up in a space in her house. She started with very few products, but thanks to her daily sales, her business is rapidly growing. This activity has given Yubes the opportunity to interact with almost all her neighbors, whom she did not know before, and her charm and good service makes them return regularly to her store. Also, as another source of income,Yubes sells food and beverages in the evenings in a space that she sets up daily outside her house. Her hopes are that her store grows and evolves into a mini-market. This is her third loan with MFP, and she likes to work with her group because they are organized and involved in the activities of the community bank. The proceeds if this loan will be used to build up her business, buying the necessary products to stock her store

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthol C., 40, and her husband, Mr. Sarun C., 47, were married in 1985 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their daughters is a garment factory worker, three children are in school and the other one is still too young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chanthol has been selling onsorm cake for fish for three years (onsorm is a kind of Cambodian cake that has rice, coconut with soybean and pork in the middle). She buys ingredients in the market in Phnom Penh to make onsorm at her house and carry it to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder for over two years.

Chanthol is requesting a loan of $500 to landfill and concrete her house foundation.

loans.use: To landfill and concrete her house foundation

loans.name: Luisa Ercilia

texts.es: La señora Luisa Ercilia tiene la edad de 52 años, se dedica a la venta de fritanga desde hace diecinueve años,  el cual inicio con dinero que su esposo dio,  reside en un bario Máximo Jerez en la capital de Managua, , su esposo labora como asistente en una empresa privada, tiene tres hijos de 3,18 y 31 años de edad, el mayor es independiente, y los dos estudian. Sus planes es poder invertir más en el negocio en la compra de mesas y sillas para brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes y atraer clientes nuevos. Con este crédito va a comprar carnes y granos básicos para preparar sus ricos platillo de comida. Da las gracias Afodenic por la oportunidad de los préstamos y plazo que nos benefician para crecer en nuestro negocio.
texts.en:
Luisa Ercilia is 52 years old and has had her own business selling fritanga (traditional Nicaraguan fried foods) for the past 19 years. Her husband provided the start-up capital for the business. She lives in the Máximo Jerez neighborhood of the capital city of Managua. Her husband works as an assitant at a private company, and the couple has three children, who are 13, 18, and 31 years old. Their oldest son is independent, while the younger two are in school. In the future, Luisa plans to invest in her business by buying tables and chairs in order to better serve her current clients and also draw in new clients. She will use this loan to buy meat and basic grains to prepare her delicious meals. She is thankful to Afodenic for giving her the opportunity to take out loans on terms that benefit her by allowing her to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat and basic grains

loans.name: Sheriffatu

texts.en: Sheriffatu sells frozen foods like fish, beef and chicken. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. Sheriffatu is 52 years old and has six children. She is married to B.. She says "thank you".

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 35, divorced, and has two daughters who are in school. She is very dedicated to her family. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew in her community. She started her operation about ten years ago in order to take care of her home. However, her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice, to increase her efficiency in producing larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business, to raise more income to support the growth of her business and for her children's education. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘God’s Grace’. She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and for peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood etc.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene manages a photocopying service in District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 29 years old and married to Jefone.  The couple have a five-year-old daughter named Jelene Annofe. In addition to their photocopying business, she also manages a computer printing business.

Knowing that education is important, Arlene is really doing her best to further improve their businesses for the future education of their child. Arlene wants to expand their businesses and eventually have another branch near the high school and college in Cauayan City.

To make the expansion possible, Arlene wants to borrow PHP 50,000 from Kiva lenders. With this amount, she believes that her dreams will become reality. 

She hopes to become successful in her chosen career and hopes for continuous business development.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr: Oumou F. est une dame de 53 ans, elle est mariée et a un enfant en charge. Elle est cliente du Banc Villageois de Vélingara Ouest2 depuis 6 ans et demi et y a contracté 13 prêts qu'elle a chaque fois remboursés sans difficulté. Avec son crédit elle développe un petit commerce de vente de pain de signe et de charbon. Les bénéfices de son activité lui serviront à aider son marie pour la prise en charge de la nourriture, la santé et l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille.
texts.en:
Oumou F. is a 53 year-old married woman with one child still in her care. She has been a member of the Community Bank "Velingara Ouest2" for the past 6 years and a half, and she has acquired 13 loans during that time. Each of the loans was repaid without difficulty. The loans are used to develop her small break bakery business. The earnings from her small business will help her husband in the purchase of food, healthcare and to generally improve the living conditions of her family.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop her business.

loans.name: Wan Word Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale business entrepreneurs in the small town of Waterloo, about 22 miles from Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. Business has been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs because of low capital. With the opening of an SMT branch office in partner with Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo; these women formed a group in order to solicit a loan. With a loan, their businesses will improve, they will make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

These entrepreneurs named their group Wan Word. Isha F. (left) is the leader of the group. Isha is now 44 years of age. She was born in Port Loko district, northern Sierra Leone. She now lives with her husband and four children in Waterloo. Her husband is a lorry driver and her four children are attending primary and secondary schools. Isha sells charcoal and fire woods. She has been in this business for nine years now.  With this loan, Isha expects to buy something like 100 – 200 bags of charcoal and 3,500 piles of firewood in villages near Waterloo.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Julia Margarita

texts.es:
El banco comunal Cochapamba se encuentra en la comunidad del mismo nombre a unos 45 minutos a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, vía al valle, Cochapamba se caracteriza por su geografía, tiene muchos valles y llanuras, su clima es frío y la gente de esta comunidad se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.
 
Este Banco Comunal  está conformado por un grupo de mujeres valientes dispuestas a surfear cualquier obstáculo que la vida les ponga adelante teniendo siempre una visión para el futuro.

La señora Julia V. vive en el barrio San Miguel Alto ubicado vía al  Valle en la Ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 39 años de edad  vive en unión libre y concibió 4 hijos de 19, 17, 16, 9 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos trabajan y le ayudan un poco con los gastos de la casa porque tienen otros gastos, sus otros dos hijos aun son estudiantes de primaria y secundaria, la casa en la que viven es  propia pero está a medio construiir.

Julia tiene su negocio de venta de frutas labora en este negocio hace mucho tiempo, esta actividad la realiza sólo los días de feria que son  Miércoles, Sábado y Domingo en la feria libre (en un mercado de Cuenca), también realiza otras actividades como lavar ropa ajena en diferentes casas  y en su hogar cría pollos, cuyes y chanchos, nos cuenta que le va bien en la cría de sus animales.

Julia trabaja con la Fundación desde hace seis años, manteniendo una buena relación con sus compañeras del banco comunal,  nos comenta que los créditos obtenidos  le han permitido tener una tranquilidad económica y,  con el nuevo préstamo que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le entregue lo va a invertir en la compra de  pollos,  cuyes, cerdos, comida y vitaminas para su crecimiento e incrementar su criadero. 

Su mayor sueño es  llegar a tener un puesto propio en el mercado para dedicarse exclusivamente a su negocio de frutas sin descuidar su criadero de animales
texts.en:
The Cochapamba Communal Bank is located in the community with the same name 45 minutes on the outskirts of the city of Cuenca on the way to the valley. Cochapamba is characterized by its geography. It has a lot of valleys and plains. The climate is cold. The people of the community work in farming and livestock. This Communal Bank is comprised of a group of valiant women who are prepared to ride over any obstacle they encounter while always holding a vision for the future. Julia V. lives in the San Miguel Alto neighborhood, which is located on the way to the valley in the city of Cuenca. She is 39, in a common law marriage, and has four children. The children are 19, 17, 16, and 9. The first two children work and help a little with the household expenses; they have other expenses. The other two children are still in elementary school and high school. The house they live in is hers, but it is half built. Julia has a business selling fruit. She has worked at this business for a long time. She does this only on the days of the free fair (in the market in Cuenca), which are Wednesday, Saturday, and Sunday. She also does other activities like washing other people’s clothes in different houses. At home she raises chickens, guinea pigs, and pigs. She tells us that raising animals is going well for her. Julia has worked with the Foundation for six years. She has maintained a good relationship with her colleagues in the communal bank. She tells us that the loans she received have allowed her to have economic tranquility. With the new loan from The ESPOIR Foundation she will buy chickens, guinea pigs, pigs, food, and vitamins for their growth and increase her animal farm. Her biggest dream is to have her own stall in the market so that she can devote herself to her fruit business exclusively without neglecting her animals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chickens, guinea pigs, pigs, food, and vitamins for their care

loans.name: Laurel

texts.en:
A professional chef since 1994, Laurel knows what her female colleagues in the kitchen need: appropriately-sized professional chef uniforms. "The typical chef's jacket is cut for a man. The sleeves are too long and the fit is terrible," says Laurel.

After receiving business coaching from a local resource center and interning in pattern-making at an apparel company, Laurel developed her business plan and launched Bayleaf Design Company in 2007. She continues her work as a part-time caterer and even sells sandwiches and salads to a café near her home to make ends meet as her business gets off the ground.  

Her full line of chef’s apparel is currently in production with the manufacturer and Laurel is hitting the trade show circuit this fall to pre-sell her products.  A female chef who is currently competing on a national television cooking competition already wears one of Laurel’s earliest designs. “When I talked to her about my designs, she got excited that I was finally making what every female chef knows we so desperately need!”

A $2,000 loan will allow Laurel to buy a new computer and a mobile credit card scanner to process orders at trade shows. “The timing is right and I have wonderful momentum. The food service industry is adapting to the down economy and people are still working in restaurants. It’s so exciting to see my business taking off!”

loans.use: Computer and mobile credit card scanner

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy food for livestock and more livestock to raise

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza R. is from the village of San Pedro. She is 47 years old. Liza is married and has 3 children. The eldest is an adult while the remaining 2 are school-aged. To make a living, Liza owns and operates a business venture in the aqua-culture sector, culturing oysters. The main source of income for the business comes from oyster culture known as "talaba". Liza has been engaged in her business for over 7 years with approximate average monthly earnings of 3,000 PHP.

In 2007, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. Liza is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials for oyster culture activities. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Liza from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to support the education of her children.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for aqua-culture of oysters

loans.name: Komlagan

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un jeune célibataire dynamique qui pour subvenir à ses propres besoins s’est lancé en 2007 dans le commerce de cartes de recharges TOGOCEL et ILLICO en gros et en détail. Il dispose déjà de 2 ans d’expérience professionnelle, ce qui lui permet d’avoir une maîtrise de son commerce. Actuellement son stock est en baisse raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 25 cartes de recharges TOGOCEL et 25 cartes de recharge ILLICO
texts.en:
This gentleman is a young, energetic, and unmarried man who, to provide for himself, embarked on a retail and wholesale business in 2007 selling TOGOCEL and ILLICO mobile phone recharge cards. He already has two years of professional experience, which enables him to have a command of his commerce. Currently, his inventory is low. This is why he's requesting a loan from WAGES, so as to stock up again with 25 TOGOCEL recharge cards and 25 ILLICO recharge cards.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying mobile phone cards

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en: Abiba is a 48-year-old married mother of three children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Abiba, like many other women in the community, works to support her husband to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and supplies kenkey (a local specialty). She buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities. Abiba has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk so she can supply to more customers to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Vrenda

texts.en: N. Vrenda is a 47-year-old businesswoman and is the mother of two children. She has been operating a retail shop since 2004. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items, mostly essentials like soap, paraffin, salt, sugar, drinks, sweets, etc. to expand her business. She hopes to obtain a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail shop items, mostly essentials like soap, paraffin, salt, sugar, drinks, sweets, etc.

loans.name: Akhmad

texts.en: Akhmad V. is a 48-year-old man. He is married and has three children. He sells fruits and vegetables in the central street of his home village in Agsu city. Akhmad started his business 12 years ago, and since that time, he has become a well-known entrepreneur. He sells potatoes, carrots, onions, greens, apples, and tomatoes. He applied for a loan of 1600 AZN in order to build his own shop. You can be an important part of Akhmad's business.

loans.use: To build his own store

loans.name: Keep On Trying Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Keep on Trying Group, who are small-scale businesspeople in the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They are applying to SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Fatmata K., 39, born in the village of Yele, some few miles from Magburaka. Married to a motor mechanic and the mother of five children, Fatmata has been a businesswoman for 10 years now. She sells local food items including rice, palm-oil, tomatoes, cassavas, etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by purchasing additional food items.

loans.use: Buy rice, palm-oil, tomatoes, cassavas, etc. to add to her business

loans.name: Mil

texts.en: Mil L. has her own small business and her main activity is to sell groceries in front of her home. She sells her items to people who live nearby her house. She is blessed with two kids who are pupils in primary school. Also, Mil L. relies on her husband’s income. He works in construction. Mil L. is very busy with her business due to there being a lot of clients who need her products. To satisfy her customers' needs, Mil L. is requesting a loan to order more grocery inventory for her store.

loans.use: To order more grocery inventory for her store.

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam M., a 25-year-old married mother of an infant, is from the village of Gingoog City where she owns and operates a retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Meriam has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Meriam joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, her first from HSPFI, to purchase additional products to sell, Meriam plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of her relatives.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Niño Fajardito Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Niño Fajardito inicia su cuarto ciclo con 12 socias.
Las socias son del departamento D. Huancavelica y realizan diferentes negocios.
Como es el caso D. Flor que es casada, tiene 3 hijos, Flor se dedica a la venta D. golosinas en la puerta D. su casa, para lo cual cuenta con una carreta, con sus ganancias pueD. mantener su hogar, con el préstamo que obtendrá comprara golosinas para incrementar su negocio.
Los sueños D. Flor son construir su casa y tener una tienda.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 200 soles, 300 soles, 500 soles, haciendo un total D. 4400 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
The Niño Fajardito communal bank is beginning its fourth loan cycle with 12 members.

The members are from the department of Huancavelica and have different businesses.

In the case of Flor, she is married with 3 children. She sells sweets at the door to her house, for which she has a cart. With her earnings, she is able to maintain her home. With the loan requested, she will purchase more sweets to expand her business.

Flor’s dreams are to build her house and to have a store.

The members need different loan amounts such as 200 PEN, 300 PEN, 500 PEN, making a total of 4400 PEN in loans at the communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of sweets

loans.name: Juan Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Juan Ramón G. M. es trabajador de  la Alcaldía de Chinandega se desempeña como responsable de bienes habita en el barrio ayapal es casado con dos hijos  a su cargo.

El señor Juan Ramón G. solicita crédito para mejorar sus condiciones  de vida ya que desea ampliar un poco más su casa y hacer unas reparaciones en su baño, el señor llevar ya cinco años trabajando con CEPRODEL y ha demostrado ser una persona muy responsable.
texts.en:
Juan Ramón G. M. works as an asset manager at the Chinandega City Hall. He lives in the Ayapal neighborhood, and is married with two children under his care. Mr. G. is seeking a loan to improve his quality of life. He would like to enlarge his house a bit more and do some repairs to his bathroom. He has been working with CEPRODEL for five years now and has shown himself to be a very responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc, blocks, and cement.

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina, 36 years old, supports her family with her general store. She lives in Brgy 1, Siaton, Negros Oriental, with her 39-year-old husband, Herod, who is a driver. They have three children between eight and18, all in school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000.

Monina is now borrowing Php 15,000 so that she can expand her store. This will be her sixth cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHp 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Monina aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha  is a trustworthy and hard-working woman. She is 54 years old and has been running a kindergarten for the past eight years. Martha is a widow and the mother of four children. Her oldest child is 35 and the youngest is 25 years old.  Martha always loves to take care of children. She started with taking care of her own children and eventually decided to start a kindergarten in her community. She admits kids from six months to two years old. She dreams of expanding her infrastructure to enable her to extend admission to older kids.

She currently operates her school in a rented space in her community. She is excited to be taking this loan to enable her to buy additional tables and chairs to be used by the kids and also improve the quality of the food for the kids.

loans.use: To purchase additional tables and chairs.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka is a 45 year-old owner of a kiosk.  She sells items such as milk, bread, cooking oil, flour, body oil, etc. to nearby residents.  She has been in this business for eight years.  Milka is married and has five children; two boys and three girls, aged from 10 to 28 years old. 

The primary business challenges she faces are low sales due to the low income of her customers, plus a high electricity bill for the refrigerator in her kiosk.

Milka plans to use the 60,000 KES loan to boost the stock of bread, milk, cooking oil, flour, etc. in the hope of increasing her income.

In the future, Milka hopes to expand her business to accommodate other products required by her customers.  In five years, she dreams of being the leading supplier of the products she sells to the surrounding residential area.

Milka describes herself as determined, hopeful, honest, and hardworking.

loans.use: To increase stock of goods for sale

loans.name: Mwanamkuu

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu A. is a widow with six children, four girls and two boys. Two girls are already married and the others are still attending school. She has been operating her tailoring business for three years with another source of income coming from her married daughters. Mwanamkuu sells from home, neighbors and passersby being her potential customers. Mwanamkuu is asking for a loan of Kshs 25,000  to purchase handbags and shoes for retail sale. She hopes to open a shop someday.

Mwanamkuu decided to join Yehu to access loans and to  improve her living standard. She rents a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees, rent and electricity.

loans.use: To buy brand new handbags and shoes for sale.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en:
Angelica B. is a 42-year old married woman who lives in Crossing Central Manapla, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures.  The first is food selling and the second is a sari sari (general) store.
